Award.AwardTitle: Overcoming Barriers to STEM Success for Deaf Undergraduates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gallaudet University is the world's only liberal arts university with programs and services specifically designed to accommodate deaf and hard of hearing students. Gallaudet's S-STEM project provides scholarships to deaf students majoring in biology, chemistry, or mathematics.

This project's intellectual merit results from addressing the severe under-representation of deaf individuals in STEM fields by providing a specific plan to prepare deaf students for STEM careers. The goals of this plan are realized through the following objectives: 1) recruit deaf students into STEM majors, 2) provide scholarships to talented deaf STEM students with documented financial need, 3) provide individual and group activities to support undergraduate S-STEM Scholars, 4) assist deaf S-STEM Scholars in overcoming cultural and linguistic barriers, and 5) to provide support services to deaf S-STEM Scholars to ultimately enter STEM careers.

Broader Impacts result from increasing the number of talented deaf students who choose a STEM major, and increasing the number of deaf STEM majors who are well prepared to enter STEM careers. Deaf S-STEM Scholars are interacting with deaf mentors and deaf scientists to understand that they truly can make significant contributions to STEM fields. There is a need for replicable best practices in educating deaf undergraduates in STEM disciplines, and this project can help develop such practices. Plans are in place to disseminate these best practices on Gallaudet's website for prospective students and the public. Plans are also in place to reach the STEM education community through presentations at national venues and publications in professional and higher education literature, including those that focus on teaching and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The S-STEM grant at Gallaudet university, Overcoming Barriers to STEM Success for Deaf Undergraduates grant (Award No. 1259237), resulted in the support of 21 S-STEM Scholars.

 

When the project was originally proposed, it was estimated that 14 students (juniors and seniors) would be awarded scholarships in the first year, plus 21 scholars during subsequent years, with a total of 35 scholars over a period of five years.  However, during the award negotiation with Dr. William Grisham, Program Director, Division of Undergraduate Education, the focus of the project was changed to accommodate both the entering freshmen and transfer students and support them throughout their academic career at Gallaudet. Also, measures were incorporated to provide early interventions to address the typical STEM drop-out rates seen during students' first few years in college.  As a result, the project goals were changed to support a total of 21 students over the entire course of their academic career, instead of 35 students for only part of their academic career. 

 

The S-STEM program at Gallaudet was able to recruit deaf and hard-of-hearing students who pursued majors in Chemistry, Biology, and Mathematics. The grant provided scholarships to students with documented financial needs.  At the same time, S-STEM organized several activities including mentoring for S-STEM scholars based on their majors, discussion groups around chemistry, mathematics and biology. Also, the program organized activities aimed at helping the S-STEM scholar overcome various barriers to their academic advancement.  Support and other intervention measures were provided to S-STEM scholars whose GPA fell below 3.0.

In this connection, visiting speakers were invited to present on various topics of interest, panels were arranged with former Gallaudet students on various topics including how to successfully pursue studies at Gallaudet, importance of research internships on career advancement, how to apply to graduate school/medical schools/pharmacy schools and prepare for careers in STEM and life after Gallaudet, and finally, life in graduate school and what advice they would give the current STEM majors at Gallaudet to help them prepare for graduate school.

 

S-STEM scholars attended career fairs to meet with prospective employers. Also, former students and Career Center staff were invited to give presentations on graduate school, career and internship experiences, and, on resume writing. Cohort activities were organized focusing on academic success, searching for internships, etc. At various occasions, S-STEM scholars were provided with opportunities to meet and interact with deaf and hard-of-hearing scientists. Field trips were organized to various sites of interest including the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission facility in Rockville, Maryland.  Most of the S-STEM scholars exceeded the academic criteria and were able to successfully continue with their studies at Gallaudet. Some S-STEM scholars supported the various STEM programs at Gallaudet by working as tutors and laboratory assistants where they showed good leadership skills.

S-STEM scholars were provided with guidance that enabled some to obtain summer internship opportunities and also, post-baccalaureate positions after graduation.  Also, membership dues were paid for the S-STEM scholars at professional organizations including the American Chemical Society, the American mathematical Association, and, the American Institute of Biological Science.

The S-STEM grant also supported activities that benefited the wider STEM department including inviting guest speakers, organizing alumni panels, and participation in STEP open house events.
